columns.text: In this problem, we will compare two lightbulbs that have different lifespans using the concept of equivalent annual cost.

First, we need to solve for the number of watts per hour for each of the light bulbs. In order to do this, we will simply divide the given wattage by the expected lifespan. 

For the **incandescent light bulb**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Watts per hour}&=\dfrac{60 \text{W}}{1,000}\\[15 pt]
&=0.06 \text{W}
\end{aligned}$$

The incandescent light bulb consumes $0.6$ Watts per hour.

Next, we will solve for how many kilowatts each lightbulb consumes per year. It is indicated in the problem that these bulbs are expected to work for $500$ hours per year. This means we will simply multiply the values of watts per hour by $500$.


Annual watts consumed by **incandescent light bulb**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual wattage}&=0.06 \times 500\\[15 pt]
&=30
\end{aligned}$$

The incandescent light bulb consumes $30$ Watts every year.

Annual watts consumed by **LED light bulb**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual wattage}&=0.000175 \times 500\\[15 pt]
&=0.0875
\end{aligned}$$

The LED light bulb consumes $0.0875$ Watts every year.

Now that we have the number of watts consumed per year, we can solve for the cost of each bulb. It is already indicated in the problem that a kilowatt-hour costs $\$0.121$. To do this, we will simply multiply the annual wattage to $\$0.121$.

Annual cost for **incandescent light bulb**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=00 \times \$0.121\\[15 pt]
&=\$3.63
\end{aligned}$$

The incandescent light bulb will cost $\$3.63$ annually in terms of power consumption

Annual cost for **LED light bulb**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=0.0875 \times \$0.121\\[15 pt]
&=\$0.01059
\end{aligned}$$

The LED light bulb will cost $\$0.01059$ annually in terms of power consumption

In order to solve for the annuity factor, we will first solve for the lifespan of each bulb. To do this, we will simply divide the expected hours of each bulb by $500$.

For the **incandescent light bulb**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Lifespan}&=\dfrac{1,000}{500}\\[15 pt]
&=2
\end{aligned}$$

The lifespan of an incandescent light bulb is equal to $2$

For the **LED light bulb**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Lifespan}&=\dfrac{40,000}{500}\\[15 pt]
&=80
\end{aligned}$$

The lifespan of an LED light bulb is equal to $80$

To get the annuity factor, we will use an annuity table using $10\%$ as the required return and the lifespan for the light bulbs are $2$ and $80$, respectively. 

This will give us a factor of $1.7355$ for the incandescent light bulb and $9.99512$ for the LED.

Substituting these value for the net present value, we will get:

Net present value for **incandescent light bulb**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=(\$3.63\times 1.7355)+\$0.45\\[15 pt]
&=\$6.75
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the incandescent light bulb is $\$6.75$

Net present value for **LED light bulb**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=(\$0.01059\times 9.99512)+\$2.25\\[15 pt]
&=\$2.36
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of the LED light bulb is $\$2.36$

Now that we have the net present value, we can now solve for the equivalent annual cost using the formula in Step 2.

For the incandescent light bulb:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equivalent annual cost}&=\dfrac{\$6.75}{1.7355}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3.89
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost for incandescent light bulbs is $\$3.89$

For the LED light bulb:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equivalent annual cost}&=\dfrac{\$2.36}{9.99512}\\[15 pt]
&=\$0.24
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost for LED light bulbs is $\$0.24$
Based on the computation, the LED bulb has a lower equivalent annual cost which means that it is the better choice for the firm.
